Title:
Multiple loci and morphology reveal hidden diversity in the
genus Xylophallus (Phallomycetidae, Basidiomycota)
Keywords:
Biodiversity; Fungi; molecular phylogenetics; Neotropics;
phalloid fungi; taxonomy.
Abstract:
The Amazon rainforest is the largest Neotropical Biome and
plays essential roles in terrestrial carbon storage and climate.
Although it is a highly biodiverse biome, the diversity and distribution
of fungal species are still poorly known. The Amazon rainforest is being
deforested and habitat fragmentation is a serious threat for mycobiota.
Information about fungal species diversity and distribution in Amazonia
is important, as they are important ecosystem members. Xylophallus
xylogenus is the smallest phalloid fungi described to date. Xylophallus
was considered monospecific and is geographically restricted to the
Neotropics. During field trips in Amazonia, morphological variation
within Xylophallus was observed. We evaluated five independent DNA
regions and their power for discovering putative species in the genus.
We also estimated the species trees for the genus and we tested
competing models of species delimitation using Bayes factors. The
results reveal the presence of three evolutionary units within the
genus: one is X. xylogenus; another is a new species, here named
Xylophallus clavatus; and the third clade corresponds to a new variety
of X. xylogenus that we describe as X. xylogenus var. riomadeirensis.
These findings demonstrate the mycological richness of Neotropical
forests.
